fr:title.text: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we define a new sort of "morphism" (function between gadgets, like linear transformations), it is always good practice to check if the identity function qualifies. Let V be any real vector space. We claim \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{V}\colon V\to V the identity function on V is a linear operator.
A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").
A Real Vector Space consists of a set V with two binary operators, scalar multiplication \odot \colon \mathbb {R}\times V\to V and vector addition \oplus \colon V\times V\to V, such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Closure of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v\in V;
Commutativity of \oplus : for any u,v\in V, we have u\oplus v=v\oplus u;
Associativity of \oplus : for any u,v,w\in V, we have (u\oplus v)\oplus w=u\oplus (v\oplus W);
Unit of \oplus : there exists a \vec {0}\in V such that for all u\in V we have \vec {0}+u=u and also u+\vec {0}=u;
Existence of negation: for each u\in V, there exists a -u\in V such that u\oplus -u=\vec {0};
Closure of \odot : for any real number c\in \mathbb {R} and for any u\in V, we have c\odot u\in V;
Left distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have c\odot (u\oplus v)=(c\odot u)\oplus (c\odot v);
Right distributivity of \odot over \oplus : for any c,d\in \mathbb {R} and u,v\in V, we have (c+d)\odot u=(c\odot u)\oplus (d\odot u);
Unit of \odot : for any u\in V, 1\odot u=u

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We call elements of V Vectors of V.

Notation varies book to book, especially with introductory linear algebra. Later on in Mathematics (and physics) we just write u+v for vector addition and c\cdot u or cu for scalar multiplication. But since we are trying to be explicit and clear, we demarcate vector addition and scalar multiplication with separate notation from field operations.
We could replace the real numbers \mathbb {R} with the complex numbers \mathbb {C} to define a notion of a complex vector space, nothing changes except where the scalars live.

Let \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) be the set of all m\times n matrices with entries in \mathbb {R}. If we equip \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) with matrix addition as its vector addition, and use its usual Scalar multiplication (on a matrix), then we have a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Tuples of real numbers form a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Tuples of real numbers form a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n be a real number. Let us denote by \mathbb {R}^{n} the set of all n-tuples of real numbers (x_{1},…,x_{n}). If we define (x_{1},…,x_{n})\oplus (y_{1},…,y_{n})=(x_{1}+y_{1},…,x_{n}+y_{n}) and similarly c\odot (x_{1},…,x_{n})=(cx_{1},…,cx_{n}). Then we have a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Polynomials form a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Polynomials form a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let us write down the set of all polynomials in one unknown x with real coefficients as \mathbb {R}[x]. When equipped with polynomial addition as vector addition, and scalar multiplication just multiplies each coefficient "in the obvious way", then this forms a real vector space.

fr:title.text: Vector spaces don't always have a dot product

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Vector spaces don't always have a dot product

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Not all vector spaces have a well-defined "dot product". The only one which has an obvious dot product is the vector space of n-tuples \mathbb {R}^{n}, where we define:
We will just take for granted this is a well-defined notion for \mathbb {R}^{n}.

fr:title.text: Subspace of a real vector space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace of a real vector space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space with vector addition \oplus and scalar multiplication \odot . Let U\subseteq V be a subset of vectors. We call U a Subspace of V if it forms a vector space using \oplus restricted to U, and scalar multiplication restricted to U.
This means the zero vector \vec {0}\in V must be an element of U.

fr:title.text: Criteria for a subset being a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a subset being a subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space with vector addition \oplus and scalar multiplication \odot . Then a subset U\subseteq V forms a subspace of V provided:

fr:ol.fr:li: for any u,v\in U, we have u\oplus v\in U; and
for any c\in \mathbb {R} and u\in U, we have c\odot u\in U.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Then the Trivial Subspace of V consists of just the zero vector.

fr:title.text: Subspace iff closed under arbitrary linear combinations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subspace iff closed under arbitrary linear combinations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space, let U\subseteq V. Then U is a subspace of V if and only if for every u_{1},u_{2}\in U and c_{1},c_{2}\in \mathbb {R} we have (c_{1}\odot u_{1})\oplus (c_{2}\odot u_{2})\in U.

fr:title.text: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We claim that the vector space of m\times n matrices \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) is a subspace of mn-tuples \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}.
Let v_{1},…,v_{k}\in V be vectors. We call a vector u\in V a Linear Combination of v_{1}, …, v_{k} if there exists c_{1},…,c_{k}\in \mathbb {R} such that

fr:title.text: Span of a set of vectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Span of a set of vectors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space, let S\subseteq V be a (possibly infinite) set of vectors. We define the Span of S to be the set of finite linear combinations of elements of S:
Furthermore, if W\subseteq V is a subspace of V such that \mathrm {span}(S)=W, then we call S a Spanning Set of W.
Let V be a real vector space, let S\subseteq V be a subset. Then \mathrm {span}(S) is a subspace of V.

fr:title.text: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrices are a subspace of tuples

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We claim that the vector space of m\times n matrices \mathrm {Mat}(m,n,\mathbb {R}) is a subspace of mn-tuples \mathbb {R}^{m\times n}.
Let V be a real vector space, let v_{1},…,v_{n}\in V. We say these vectors are Linearly dependent if there are coefficients c_{1},…,c_{n}\in \mathbb {R} such that:
If there are no such coefficients, then we say v_{1}, …, v_{n} are Linearly Independent.

A set of nonzero vectors \{v_{1},…,v_{n}\} of a real vector space V is linearly independent if and only if at least one of the vectors v_{k} is expressible as a linear combination of the other vectors:
where not all coefficients c_{j}\in \mathbb {R} are zero.

fr:title.text: Determinant is nonzero iff its columns are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Determinant is nonzero iff its columns are linearly independent

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix written as a list of n column vectors: \mathbf {M}=(v_{1}\mid …\mid v_{n}) Then \det (\mathbf {M})\neq 0 if and only if the columns v_{1}, …, v_{n} are linearly independent.
Let V be a real vector space, let B\subseteq V be a subset of V. If \mathrm {span}(B)=V and there is no proper subset A\subset B such that \mathrm {span}(A)=V, then we call B a Basis of V.

Let e_{j}\in \mathbb {R}^{n} have 1 in its j^{\text {th}} component and 0 in all other components. Then \{e_{1},…,e_{n}\} forms a basis of \mathbb {R}^{n} is called the Canonical Basis of \mathbb {R}^{n}.

fr:title.text: Any two bases have the same number of elements

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Any two bases have the same number of elements

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a vector space, let B be a basis for V. If B has finitely many elements, then any other basis of V has the same number of elements as B.
Let V be a real vector space.
If there is a finite basis B for V, then we define the Dimension of V to be the number \dim (V) of elements of B.
Otherwise, we define the dimension of V to be \dim (V)=\infty .
When \dim (V)<\infty , we say V is Finite-Dimensional. Otherwise V is Infinite-Dimensional.
For example, \dim (\mathbb {R}^{n})=n and \dim (\mathbb {R}[x])=\infty .
Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. We define an Ordered Basis of V to be a tuple (f_{1},…,f_{n}) of vectors f_{i}\in V for each i=1,…,n such that B=\{f_{1},…,f_{n}\} is a basis of V.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space with a well-defined notion of a dot product, let B be a basis of V. We call B an Orthogonal Basis of V if for all f_{i},f_{j}\in B we have f_{i}\cdot f_{j}=0 when i\neq j.

Note: we do not require B to be an ordered basis for us to discuss an orthogonal basis. If we want to stress that B is ordered and orthogonal, then we will speak of it as an "orthogonal ordered basis" of V.

fr:title.text: Coordinates of a vector relative to a basis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coordinates of a vector relative to a basis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let B=(e_{1},…,e_{n}) and C=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be two ordered bases of V. We may define the Change of Basis Matrix from B to C as the matrix M^{B}_{C}=([e_{1}]_{C}\mid …\mid [e_{n}]_{C}) so any vector v\in V expressed in coordinates [v]_{B} relative to B may give us the coordinates of v relative to C as [v]_{C}=M^{B}_{C}[v]_{B}. The subscript and superscripts are intended to convey an intuition that they behave "like" fractions. (Einstein is credited/blamed for this sort of convention.)

fr:title.text: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space, let B and C be ordered bases of V. Then the change of basis matrix for these two bases are related by: \mathbf {M}^{C}_{B}=(\mathbf {M}^{B}_{C})^{-1}

fr:title.text: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Change of base matrix and matrix inverse

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space, let B and C be ordered bases of V. Then the change of basis matrix for these two bases are related by: \mathbf {M}^{C}_{B}=(\mathbf {M}^{B}_{C})^{-1}

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space with a well-defined notion of a dot product. Let x_{1},…,x_{m}\in V be linearly independent vectors. Then we may form m orthonormal vectors (which form an orthonormal ordered basis if \dim (V)=m) by the following algorithm:
Step 1: Set f_{1}=\widehat {x}_{1} to be the unit vector of x_{1}.
Step 2: For each x_{2}, …, x_{m}, compute v_{k} by v_{k}=x_{k}-\sum ^{k-1}_{j=1}(x_{k}\cdot f_{j})f_{j}, and then we set f_{k}=\widehat {v_{k}}=\frac {v_{k}}{\sqrt {v_{k}\cdot v_{k}}}.
This will produce an ordered tuple (f_{1},…,f_{m}) of orthonormal vectors of V.
We can equivalently note that we can use projections to form a bunch of orthogonal vectors:

Let V be a real vector space with a well-defined notion of dot product (or some way to compute the projection of one vector along another). Let u,v\in V. Assume u\neq \vec {0}. We define the Decomposition of v with respect to u as consisting of two vectors of V:

fr:ol.fr:li: The parallel part v^{\parallel }=\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v), and
The perpedincular part v^{\bot }=v-v^{\parallel }.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be real vector spaces. A Linear Transformation from V to W is a function L\colon V\to W such that for all u,v\in V and coefficients c_{1},c_{2}\in \mathbb {R} we have L(c_{1}u+c_{2}v)=c_{1}L(u)+c_{2}L(v). If further V=W, then we call L a Linear Operator.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let u\in V be a nonzero vector u\neq \vec {0}. Then projection along u \mathrm {Proj}_{u}(-) is a linear operator on V. To see this, we check \mathrm {Proj}_{u}(c_{1}v_{1}+c_{2}v_{2})=c_{1}\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v_{1})+c_{2}\mathrm {Proj}_{u}(v_{2}) for any v_{1},v_{2}\in V due to basic properties of the dot product.

fr:title.text: Translation is not a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Translation is not a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Let u\in V be a nonzero vector u\neq \vec {0}. The function f\colon V\to V defined by f(v)=u+v is not a linear transformation.
To see this, we find f(v+w)=u+(v+w) but f(v)+f(w)=(u+v)+(u+w)=2u+(v+w), and u\neq 2u unless u=\vec {0}. So f cannot possibly be a linear transformation.

Let V be a finite-dimensional real vector space. Let \widehat {x}\in V be a unit vector. We define the Householder transformation with respect to \widehat {x} to be the function H_{x}\colon V\to V sending H_{x}(v)=v-(\widehat {x}\cdot v)\widehat {x} which appeared in our discussion of Orthogonal decomposition.
We see that H_{x} is a linear transformation.

fr:title.text: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function is a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: When we define a new sort of "morphism" (function between gadgets, like linear transformations), it is always good practice to check if the identity function qualifies. Let V be any real vector space. We claim \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{V}\colon V\to V the identity function on V is a linear operator.
Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define the Image (or Range) of f to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (f)=f(X)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in X\}.

fr:title.text: Domain and codomain of a function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain and codomain of a function

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define:

fr:ol.fr:li: The Domain of f to be the set \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (f):=X consisting of the inputs;
The Codomain of f to be the set \mathop {\textrm {cod}}\nolimits (f):=Y consisting of all possible outputs.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Caution: the image is always a subset of the codomain of a function, but the domain could be larger than the image of a function.

Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. If there is a function g\colon Y\to X such that g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X} and f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y}, where (g\circ f)(x)=g(f(x)) and (f\circ g)(y)=f(g(y)) for x\in X and y\in Y are the compositions of g and f, then we call g the Inverse Function of f.
When an inverse function of f exists, we denote it by f^{-1}.

fr:title.text: Inverse of linear operator is a linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inverse of linear operator is a linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V be a real vector space. Let L\colon V\to V be a linear operator of V. If there exists an inverse function L^{-1}\colon V\to V, then L^{-1} is a linear operator on V.

More generally, if we have two linear transformations L_{1}\colon V\to W and L_{2}\colon W\to X, then their composition L_{2}\circ L_{1} is a linear transformation from V to X. The result follows from the fact \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{V} and L are linear operators.

Let V and W be finite-dimensional real vector spaces. Let B_{V}=(e_{1},…,e_{m}) and B_{W}=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be ordered bases for V and W, respectively. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation. Then we define the Matrix of L relative to bases B_{V} and B_{W} to be the n\times m matrix \mathbf {M} such that the j^{\text {th}} column is given by the coordinates [L(e_{j})]_{B_{W}}.

fr:title.text: Coordinates of vector compatible with matrix of a linear transformation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coordinates of vector compatible with matrix of a linear transformation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let V and W be finite-dimensional real vector spaces. Let B_{V}=(e_{1},…,e_{m}) and B_{W}=(f_{1},…,f_{n}) be ordered bases for V and W, respectively. Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation. Let \mathbf {M} be the matrix of L relative to bases B_{V} and B_{W}. Then for any vector v\in V, we have [L(v)]_{B_{W}}=M[v]_{B_{V}}. In other words, "this stuff works together".
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Surjective (or that it's a surjection) if for each y\in Y there is at least one x\in X such that f(x)=y.
In other words, the image of f is the codomain of f. Or more vividly, f "covers" all of Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is injective (or that it's a injection) if for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X such that f(x_{1})=f(x_{2}) we have x_{1}=x_{2}.
Equivalently, if f(x_{1})\neq f(x_{2}), then x_{1}\neq x_{2}.
So no two distinct elements of X are mapped to the same element under f.
We say a function f\colon X\to Y is Bijective (or say f is a bijection) if f is both injective and surjective.
This means for each y\in Y, there exists a unique x\in X such that f(x)=y.

Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. We define the Kernel of L to be the subset \ker (L)\subseteq V equal to \ker (L)=\{v\in V\mid L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}\}. In other words, the kernel consists of all elements of V which are mapped to the zero vector of W.

fr:title.text: Kernel of linear transformation is a subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kernel of linear transformation is a subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces V and W. Then \ker (L) is a subspace of V.
We see that for any v\in \ker (L) and c\in \mathbb {R} that L(cv)=cL(v) by linearity and cL(v)=c\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W}, so cv\in \ker (L).
For any u,v\in \ker (L), we see L(u+v)=L(u)+L(v) by linearity, and L(u)+L(v)=\vec {0}_{W}+\vec {0}_{W}=\vec {0}_{W} by definition of the kernel. Hence u+v\in \ker (L).
Hence by the Criteria for a subset being a subspace, we see \ker (L) is a subspace of V.

fr:title.text: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial subspace

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear transformation is injective iff kernel is trivial subspace

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. Then L is injective if and only if \ker (L)=0_{V} is the Trivial subspace of V.

The forward direction: assume L is injective. For any v\in V such that v
eq \vec {0}_{V}, we have L(v)
eq L(\vec {0}_{V}) by definition of injective functions, and this means L(v)
eq \vec {0}_{W} by the fact linear transformations map the zero vector to the zero vector.

The backward direction: assume \ker (L)=0_{V}=\{\vec {0}_{V}\}. For any v_{1},v_{2}\in V such that L(v_{1})=L(v_{2}), we will prove v_{1}=v_{2}. First, we see L(v_{1})-L(v_{2})=\vec {0}_{W} and then by linearity, the left-hand side becomes L(v_{1}-v_{2})=\vec {0}_{W}. Then v_{1}-v_{2}\in \ker (L) by definition of the kernel. Then v_{1}-v_{2}\in \{\vec {0}_{V}\}, which means v_{1}-v_{2}=\vec {0}_{V}. Then adding v_{2} to both sides gives us v_{1}=v_{2}, as desired. Hence L is injective.
Let L\colon V\to W be a linear transformation of real vector spaces. Then \dim (\ker (L))+\dim (L(V))=\dim (V).

fr:title.text: Eigenvalue and Eigenvector of linear operator

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eigenvalue and Eigenvector of linear operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let L\colon V\to V be a real linear operator. If there exists a nonzero vector v\in V and a nonzero \lambda \in \mathbb {R} such that L(v)=\lambda v, then we call v the Eigenvector of L with Eigenvalue \lambda .

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix with coefficients in the real numbers \mathbb {R} or complex numbers \mathbb {C} (or more generally some Field). If there is an n-column vector v which is the zero vector, and if there is a nonzero number \lambda such that \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v then we call v the Eigenvector of \mathbf {M} with Eigenvalue \lambda .
Let \mathbf {M} be a n\times n matrix over the reals (or some Field). We define the Characteristic Polynomial of \mathbf {M} to be the polynomial p(\lambda )=\det (\mathbf {A}-\lambda \mathbf {I}).

Why is this a good notion? Well, with the eigenstuff for a matrix \mathbf {M}v=\lambda v we have \mathbf {M}v-\lambda v=0. But this is really (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})v=0. Then \mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I} is a linear operator, and we're looking for its kernel. The kernel is nontrivial if the determinant is zero, which means we want to find the values \lambda such that \det (\mathbf {M}-\lambda \mathbf {I})=0. But this is precisely the characteristic polynomial as we have defined it.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. Let \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n} be its eigenvalues. Then the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues of the matrix, i.e., \det (\mathbf {M})=\prod ^{n}_{j=1}\lambda _{j}.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. Let \lambda _{1}, …, \lambda _{n} be its eigenvalues. Then the trace of \mathbf {M} is just the sum of its eigenvalues of the matrix, i.e., \mathrm {tr}(\mathbf {M})=\sum ^{n}_{j=1}\lambda _{j}.

Let \mathbf {M} be an n\times n matrix. We say \mathbf {M} is Diagonalizable if there exists a diagonal matrix \mathbf {D} such that \mathbf {M}\sim \mathbf {D}, i.e., if there exists an invertible matrix \mathbf {P} such that \mathbf {P}^{-1}\mathbf {D}\mathbf {P}=\mathbf {M}.
Let \mathbf {A} and \mathbf {B} be n\times n matrices. If they are similar to each other \mathbf {A}\sim \mathbf {B}, then they have the same eigenvalues.

fr:title.text: Matrix is diagonalizable iff it has linearly independent eigenvectors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix is diagonalizable iff it has linearly independent eigenvectors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {A} be an n\times n matrix. Then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable if and only if \mathbf {A} has n linearly independent eigenvectors.

fr:title.text: Matrix is diagonalizable when the roots of its characteristic polynomial are unique

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Matrix is diagonalizable when the roots of its characteristic polynomial are unique

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbf {A} be an n\times n matrix. If the roots of the characteristic polynomial of \mathbf {A} are all distinct (i.e., the set of all roots is a set with n distinct elements), then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable.

Let \mathbf {A} be a real n\times n matrix. Assume \det (\mathbf {A})\neq 0. Then \mathbf {A} is diagonalizable by an orthogonal matrix \mathbf {P} (i.e., \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {P}\mathbf {D}\mathbf {P}^{-1} where \mathbf {D} is a diagonal matrix and \mathbf {P}^{-1}=\mathbf {P}^{\mathsf {T}}) if and only if \mathbf {A} is symmetric \mathbf {A}=\mathbf {A}^{\mathsf {T}}.
